awd_titl_txt: Very High Energy Gamma-ray Astrophysics with VERITAS
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to perform high-sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources.  This award supports scientists at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities in their research with VERITAS.  The group will participate in both technical operations in support of the observatory and scientific investigations of high energy gamma ray emission from active galaxies.  The University of Minnesota group is engaged in citizen science efforts to classify gamma-ray data through the Zooniverse.org platform.  The group will also engage undergraduates with VERITAS research experiences and participate in public outreach at local events.

This University of Minnesota group will implement new analysis methods to improve the sensitivity of VERITAS to weak sources and to address systematic uncertainties at the highest energies.  With these improvements the group will perform scientific analyses of both new and archival VERITAS data to study Active Galactic Nuclei.  They will focus on characterizing new classes of very high energy emitting sources, including radio galaxies and extreme blazars to study the "blazar sequence."  They will also perform multi-wavelength studies on blazars to probe the gamma-ray emission zone and to set limits on the extragalactic background light through its effects on blazar intrinsic spectra.  In their work with Zooniverse.org, the group will crowd-source classifications of camera images, providing important training data for the improvement of image classification algorithms while at the same time engaging the public in gamma-ray related science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Minnesota VERITAS team seeks to understand the mechanisms by which certain Active Galactic Nuclei known as blazars emit gamma-ray radiation above 100 GeV in large-scale jets of plasma emanating from the central black hole in the galaxy. Since blazars emit across all wavebands – from radio to optical to X-ray and gamma-ray - the approach used comprises gathering data from all these wavebands to investigate the potential correlations between them. These data are then used to test the dominant theory that gamma rays are emitted from a blob of electrons that are accelerated perhaps due to a shock within the plasma jet. The accelerated electrons produce synchrotron radiation which itself scatters on the same electron population producing higher-energy photons up to gamma rays. To test these models, the UMN team led the successful effort to detect unusual flaring episodes from classic known blazars as well as to discover new blazars including radio galaxies where the angle of the jet is mis-aligned with respect to the direct line to Earth.  Results from this work show that in many cases, but crucially not in all, this so-called synchrotron self-Compton model works well in explaining the gamma-ray emission. In the case of radio galaxies, flaring episodes analyzed by the UMN team show some evidence for the gamma-ray emission coming from a radio component ejected from the core several decades ago and now traveling down the jet. These data will be used by modelers to develop more refined theories to explain the range of gamma-ray behavior observed in blazars.

To support the above research, the UMN VERITAS team developed and implemented critical software components including the main analysis package used by the entire VERITAS collaboration for multiple research aims. In addition, the team is developing deep learning models to improve the separation of the signal gamma-ray events from the background cosmic-ray events.

The UMN VERITAS team also led the successful citizen science project Muon Hunter which used the Zooniverse platform to gather over 2 million volunteer classifications on 140,000 images to determine whether an image contained a muon ring or not, and if so, to draw an outline around the muon ring. Muon rings are by-products of air showers that are detected by the VERITAS cameras and due to their regular properties can be used to calibrate the VERITAS system. However, the software to select them can be cumbersome so the idea behind Muon Hunter was to train a deep learning algorithm to do better at selecting muons. Deep learning algorithms need quite a lot of training labels and the citizen science project was able to provide these very successfully. A follow-on version, Muon Hunter 2.0 (MH2), used a deep learning technique called unsupervised clustering to generate groups of images that share similar features; images within these clusters were then sampled and provided to volunteers for labeling within a 6x6 grid of images. This enabled a label purification process to be efficiently applied, reducing by 72% the total number of clicks required to provide image labels. With the aid of the deep learning algorithm, an improved muon calibration pipeline was developed.
